original_title: Sri Lanka’s shares up at close on banking sector
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka shares were up at close on Thursday after buying interest was channeled in the banking sector on clarity on debt restructuring, after the market was down on profit taking due to continuous gains, an analyst said.
The main All Share Price Index was up 2.48 percent or 272.74 points to 11,257.82, while S&P SL20 was up 3.36 percent or 106.39 points to 3,273.76.
“Buying interest was seen in blue chip counters and the banking sector, because concerns have been lifted with regard to debt optimization and macroeconomic factors,” an analyst said.

The market generated a turnover of 3.3 billion rupees, the banking sector 1.1 billion rupees, the capital sector brought in 804 million rupees and the diversified financials brought in 508 million rupees, while the yearly average stands at 1.7 billion rupees.
The market generated a net foreign inflow of 695 million rupees.
Sri Lanka’s announced domestic debt restructuring plan has avoided adding to the “fragility” of the banking system, World bank Country Director Faris Hadad-Zervos said.
Sri Lanka kept banks, which have already been hit by bad loans and mark-to-market losses out of re-structuring plan.
Gainers during trade were Commercial Bank, Sampath Bank and Hatton National Bank.  (Colombo/July27/2023)
